facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 137 to 141 of 1958 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 137 to 141 of 1958. Appeals by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgment and order dated April 26, 1956 of Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Cases Nos. 362 to 366 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 26, 1956 of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Cases Nos. 362 to 366 of 1955. V. Viswanatha Sastri, S. K. Majumdar and I. N. Shroff, for the appellants Nos. 2 to 4  In all the appeals

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 15, 1960 by KAPUR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. December 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-The assessee who is the appellant has brought these five appeals against the judgment and order of the High Court of Patna by which it answered the two questions stated under s. 66 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act against the appellant and in favour of the Commissioner of Income- tax.

facts.text: Appellant is son of late Maharajadhiraja of Darbhanga and brother of present Maharaja.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee who is the appellant has brought these five appeals against the judgment and order of the High Court of Patna by which it answered the two questions stated under s. 66 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act against the appellant and in favour of the Commissioner of Income- tax. The appellant is the son of the late Maharajadhiraja of Darbhanga and the brother of the present Maharaja.

facts.text: Father died in 1929.

anchor.surface_text: The father died in 1929 and the appellant was given by way of maintenance the Estate of Rajnagar. He was also given a yearly allowance of Rs. 30,000 which was later raised to Rs. 48,000.

facts.text: Appellant given Estate of Rajnagar by way of maintenance and yearly allowance of Rs. 30,000 later raised to Rs. 48,000.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellant was given by way of maintenance the Estate of Rajnagar. He was also given a yearly allowance of Rs. 30,000 which was later raised to Rs. 48,000. From 1929, the appellant invested his cash surplus in shares and securities, the account of which was entered in what is called Account Book No. 1.

facts.text: From 1929, appellant invested cash surplus in shares and securities entered in Account Book No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: From 1929, the appellant invested his cash surplus in shares and securities, the account of which was entered in what is called Account Book No. 1. From the year 1930 onwards up to the year 1941-42 the appellant purchased a large number of shares and securities which by the accounting year 1941-42 were of the value of Rs. 14.91 lacs.

facts.text: From 1930 to 1941-42, appellant purchased shares and securities worth Rs. 14.91 lacs by 1941-42.

anchor.surface_text: From the year 1930 onwards up to the year 1941-42 the appellant purchased a large number of shares and securities which by the accounting year 1941-42 were of the value of Rs. 14.91 lacs. During this period the appellant sold shares and securities in the accounting years 1936-37 and 1939-40 of the value of 1.48 lacs and 1.69 lacs respectively.

facts.text: Sold shares in 1936-37 value Rs. 1.48 lacs and 1939-40 Rs. 1.69 lacs, profits assessed to tax.

anchor.surface_text: During this period the appellant sold shares and securities in the accounting years 1936-37 and 1939-40 of the value of 1.48 lacs and 1.69 lacs respectively. He made certain amount of profits on these sales but under orders of the Commissioner of Income-tax in the former case and of the Income-tax Tribunal in the latter case, these sums were number assessed to income-tax.

facts.text: In 1942-43 to 1946-47, appellant purchased and sold shares and securities as per table: 1942-43 beginning Rs.14.66 lacs, purchased Nil, sold Rs.4.68 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: In the accounting years 1942-43 to 1946-47 the appellant purchased and sold some shares and securities. The entries in Account No. 1 stood as follows- Total value of Total companyt of Total companyt of shares shares securities shares and and securities sold companyt at the securities pur during the year. beginning of the chased during the year. year. 1350 Fs. Rs. 14.66 lacs Nil Rs. 4.68 lacs 942-43  13 items

facts.text: Profits in those years: 1942-43 Rs. 2,56,959 to 1946-47 Rs. 33,174.

anchor.surface_text: and in all these years the appellant made profits which varied from Rs. 2,56,959 in the accounting year 194243 to Rs. 33,174 in the accounting year 1946-47.

facts.text: On July 16, 1940, appellant arranged overdraft with Mercantile Bank of India, withdrew Rs. 10,000 for shares.

anchor.surface_text: On July 16, 1940, the appellant arranged an overdraft with the Mercantile Bank of India and actually withdrew Rs. 10,000 for the purchase of shares. But his brother the Maharaja advanced to him without interest Rs. 10 lacs and thus the overdraft was paid off.

facts.text: Brother Maharaja advanced Rs. 10 lacs interest-free, paid off overdraft.

anchor.surface_text: But his brother the Maharaja advanced to him without interest Rs. 10 lacs and thus the overdraft was paid off. A new Account was opened in the books of the appellant named No. 2 Investment Account which companytained all entries in regard to shares purchased and sold from out of the money borrowed from the Maharajadhiraj.

facts.text: New Account No. 2 Investment Account opened for shares from borrowed money.

anchor.surface_text: A new Account was opened in the books of the appellant named No. 2 Investment Account which companytained all entries in regard to shares purchased and sold from out of the money borrowed from the Maharajadhiraj.

In the third period, i.e., the assessment years 1944-45 to 1948-49 the profits made by the appellant from purchase and sale of shares were as follows- 1944-45Rs.2,62,000 and odd 1945-46Rs.3,95,000 and odd 1946-47Rs.1,57,000 and odd 1947-48Rs.1,33,000 and odd 1948-49Rs. 76,000 and odd The Income-Tax Officer held these to be liable to income-tax as business profits.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held profits liable as business profits.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-Tax Officer held these to be liable to income-tax as business profits. On appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner excluded the profits for the years 1944-45 and 1945-46 but for the years 1946-47 to 1948-49 the assessments were upheld.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner excluded profits for 1944-45 and 1945-46, upheld 1946-47 to 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner excluded the profits for the years 1944-45 and 1945-46 but for the years 1946-47 to 1948-49 the assessments were upheld. Both parties appealed to the Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held appellant was dealer in shares and securities, profits assessable.

anchor.surface_text: It held on the evidence that the appellant was to be regarded as a dealer in shares and securities and therefore the profits were assessable to income-tax.

facts.text: Appellant applied for case stated under s.66(1), dismissed; High Court ordered under s.66(2).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant applied for a case to be stated under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act. This application was dismissed but the High Court made an order under s. 66 2  of the Income-tax Act to state a case on two questions of law.

facts.text: Two questions referred to High Court, answered against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The questions were as follows Whether in the circumstances of the case, there is material to support the finding of the Appellate Tribunal that the assessee was a dealer in shares and securities with respect to each of the accounts and, therefore, liable to be taxed? Whether, having regard to the findings of the Appellate Tribunal in respect of 1941/42 assessment, it was open to the Appellate Tribunal in the present case to hold that the profits and the transactions of sale and purchase of shares and securities amounted to profits of business and so liable to be taxed ?

facts.text: Patna High Court answered both questions in affirmative against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the facts and circumstances which the Tribunal took into companysideration in arriving at the finding were the material before the Tribunal to support the finding and the first question was answered in the affirmative and therefore against the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant argued purchases and sales were investments of surplus monies, not business.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellant that he was number carrying on the business of buying and selling shares but his purchases and sales were in the nature of investments of his surplus monies and therefore the excess amounts received by sales were capital receipts being merely surplus and number profits.

facts.text: Appellant is zamindar with large income, investing surplus.

anchor.surface_text: It was also submitted that the appellant being a zamindar the buying and selling of shares was number his numbermal activity that he had a large income and it was his surplus income which he was investing in buying the shares and whenever he found it profitable he companyverted his holdings and securities

facts.text: In July 1948 appellant borrowed Rs.10,00,000 without interest from brother.

anchor.surface_text: In July 1948 the appellant had borrowed, though without interest, a large sum of money to the extent of about Rs. 10,00,000, numberdoubt from his brother. He started a new account calling it No. 2 Investment Account.

facts.text: Supreme Court held there was material to support Tribunal's finding that appellant was dealing in shares as business.

anchor.surface_text: if on this material the Tribunal came to the companyclusion that there was material to support the finding that the appellant was dealing in shares as a business, it companyld number be interfered with by the High Court and in our opinion it rightly answered the question against the appellant in the affirmative.

facts.text: No res judicata in income-tax matters.

anchor.surface_text: The second question is wholly unsubstantial. There is numbersuch thing as res judicata in income-tax matters.

facts.text: Appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court rightly held against the appellant. The appeals are therefore dismissed with companyts.

arguments.claim: Principle: Realisation of ordinary investment at profit is capital accretion, not taxable; but if carrying on business, assessable

anchor.surface_text: It is number necessary to discuss these cases becausethe principle applicable to such transactions is thatwhen an owner of an ordinary investment chooses to realise it and obtains a higher price for it than he originally acquired it at, the enhanced price is number a profit assessable to income tax but where as in the present case what is done is number merely a realisation or a change of investment but an act done in what is truly the carrying on of a business the amount recovered as appreciation will be assessable.

anchor.surface_text: The principle which is applicable to the present case is what we have said above and on the evidence which was before the Tribunal, i.e., the substantial nature of the transactions, the manner in which the books had been maintained, the magnitude of the shares purchased and sold and the ratio between the purchases and sales and the holdings,

arguments.claim: No res judicata in income-tax matters; Tribunal not bound by prior assessment findings

anchor.surface_text: The second question is wholly unsubstantial. There is numbersuch thing as res judicata in income-tax matters. The Appellate Tribunal has placed in a tabulated form the activities of the appellant showing the buying and selling and the magnitude of holdings and it cannot be said therefore that it was number open to the Appellate Tribunal to give the finding that it did.

holdings.text: The principle applicable to transactions in shares is that realisation of an ordinary investment at a higher price is not taxable as profit, but if it constitutes carrying on a business, the appreciation is assessable as income.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to discuss these cases becausethe principle applicable to such transactions is thatwhen an owner of an ordinary investment chooses to realise it and obtains a higher price for it than he originally acquired it at, the enhanced price is not a profit assessable to income tax but where as in the present case what is done is not merely a realisation or a change of investment but an act done in what is truly the carrying on of a business the amount recovered as appreciation will be assessable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes ordinary investor realising securities (capital accretion) from dealer or business activity (taxable income), drawing from precedents like Kamakshya Narain Singh.

holdings.text: On the facts, the assessee's transactions in shares constitute carrying on a business rather than mere realisation of investments, making profits taxable.

anchor.surface_text: The question which the High Court had to answer in the present case was a narrow one and the answer to that on the material before the Court was rightly given in the affirmative. But even if the question is taken to be wider in amplitude, on the materials produced and on the facts proved the appellant must be held to have been rightly assessed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even interpreting question broadly, materials and facts prove business activity, not investment.

holdings.text: There was material before the Tribunal to support the finding that the appellant was dealing in shares as a business; High Court rightly did not interfere and answered first question affirmatively.

anchor.surface_text: if on this material the Tribunal came to the conclusion that there was material to support the finding that the appellant was dealing in shares as a business, it could not be interfered with by the High Court and in our opinion it rightly answered the question against the appellant in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of substantial transactions, book maintenance, magnitude of purchases/sales, ratio of sales to purchases/holdings suffices; finding of fact not to be disturbed.

holdings.text: There is no res judicata in income-tax matters; Tribunal was not barred by its prior finding in 1941/42 assessment from holding profits as business income.

anchor.surface_text: The second question is wholly unsubstantial. There is no such thing as res judicata in income-tax matters. The Appellate Tribunal has placed in a tabulated form the activities of the appellant showing the buying and selling and the magnitude of holdings and it cannot be said therefore that it was not open to the Appellate Tribunal to give the finding that it did.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Doctrine of res judicata does not apply to income-tax proceedings; each assessment year independent; Tribunal reviewed fresh evidence.

precedents.citation: G. Venkataswami Naidu Co. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax  1

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant relied upon certain cases in support of his submission that the first question raised was of a wider amplitude and that it had been erroneously restricted by the High Court and that its true import was the same as of the questions which were raised in the following cases decided by this Court. He relied on G. Venkataswami Naidu Co. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax  1 , Oriental Investment Co., Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay  2 .

precedents.case_name: G Venkataswami Naidu Co v Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: question whether transaction is adventure in nature of trade is mixed question of law and fact requiring consideration of legal requirements of trade; intention to hold vs intention to resell at profit
precedents.cited_holding: purchase solely with intention to resell at profit is adventure in trade; otherwise capital accretion

precedents.citation: Oriental Investment Co., Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay  2

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant relied upon certain cases in support of his submission that the first question raised was of a wider amplitude and that it had been erroneously restricted by the High Court and that its true import was the same as of the questions which were raised in the following cases decided by this Court. He relied on G. Venkataswami Naidu Co. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax  1 , Oriental Investment Co., Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay  2 .

precedents.case_name: Oriental Investment Co Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: question whether assessee's activities amount to dealing in shares or mere investment is mixed question of law and fact; legal effect of facts is question of law

anchor.surface_text: In the Oriental Investment case 1  the assessee was an investment company. It had purchased certain shares and sold them and qua those shares it claimed to be treated as an investor and not a dealer on the ground that it did not carry on any business in the purchase and sale of shares. The assessee's applications for reference to the High Court were rejected on the ground that no question of law arose out of the order of the Tribunal.

precedents.case_name: Oriental Investment Co Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: question whether business amounted to dealing in shares or merely investment was mixed question of law and fact

precedents.citation: Raja Bahadur Kamakshya Narain Singh v. The Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bihar Orissa  1

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant argued that the amounts received by him in the accounting years were in the nature of capital accretions and therefore not assessable. In support, Counsel for the appellant relied on the following cases-Raja Bahadur Kamakshya Narain Singh v. The Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bihar Orissa  1  where Lord Wright observed that profits realised by the sale of shares may be capital if the seller is an ordinary investor changing his securities but in some instances it may be income if the seller of the shares is an investment company or an insurance company.

precedents.case_name: Raja Bahadur Kamakshya Narain Singh v Commissioner of Income-Tax Bihar and Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: profits from sale of shares are capital accretion if seller is ordinary investor changing securities; income if investment company carrying on such activity
precedents.cited_holding: profits realised by the sale of shares may be capital if the seller is an ordinary investor changing his securities

precedents.citation: Californian Copper Syndicate Limited v. Harris  2

anchor.surface_text: The other cases relied upon were Californian Copper Syndicate Limited v. Harris  2  Cooper Stubbs  3  Leeming v. Jones  4  and Edwards v. Bairstow Harrison  5 . It is not necessary to discuss these cases because the principle applicable to such transactions is that when an owner of an ordinary investment chooses to realise it and obtains a higher price for it than he originally acquired it at, the enhanced price is not a profit assessable to income tax but where as in the present case what is done is not merely a realisation or a change of investment but an act done in what is truly the carrying on of a business the amount recovered as appreciation will be assessable.

precedents.case_name: Californian Copper Syndicate Ltd v Harris
precedents.cited_proposition: amounts received from sale of investments are capital accretions not assessable as income

anchor.surface_text: The other cases relied upon were Californian Copper Syndicate Limited v. Harris  2  Cooper Stubbs  3  Leeming v. Jones  4  and Edwards v. Bairstow Harrison  5 . It is not necessary to discuss these cases because the principle applicable to such transactions is that when an owner of an ordinary investment chooses to realise it and obtains a higher price for it than he originally acquired it at, the enhanced price is not a profit assessable to income tax but where as in the present case what is done is not merely a realisation or a change of investment but an act done in what is truly the carrying on of a business the amount recovered as appreciation will be assessable.

precedents.cited_proposition: amounts received from sale of investments are capital accretions not assessable as income

anchor.surface_text: The other cases relied upon were Californian Copper Syndicate Limited v. Harris  2  Cooper Stubbs  3  Leeming v. Jones  4  and Edwards v. Bairstow Harrison  5 . It is not necessary to discuss these cases because the principle applicable to such transactions is that when an owner of an ordinary investment chooses to realise it and obtains a higher price for it than he originally acquired it at, the enhanced price is not a profit assessable to income tax but where as in the present case what is done is not merely a realisation or a change of investment but an act done in what is truly the carrying on of a business the amount recovered as appreciation will be assessable.

precedents.cited_proposition: amounts received from sale of investments are capital accretions not assessable as income

anchor.surface_text: The other cases relied upon were Californian Copper Syndicate Limited v. Harris  2  Cooper Stubbs  3  Leeming v. Jones  4  and Edwards v. Bairstow Harrison  5 . It is not necessary to discuss these cases because the principle applicable to such transactions is that when an owner of an ordinary investment chooses to realise it and obtains a higher price for it than he originally acquired it at, the enhanced price is not a profit assessable to income tax but where as in the present case what is done is not merely a realisation or a change of investment but an act done in what is truly the carrying on of a business the amount recovered as appreciation will be assessable.

precedents.cited_proposition: amounts received from sale of investments are capital accretions not assessable as income

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to discuss these cases becausethe principle applicable to such transactions is thatwhen an owner of an ordinary investment chooses to realise it and obtains a higher price for it than he originally acquired it at, the enhanced price is not a profit assessable to income tax but where as in the present case what is done is not merely a realisation or a change of investment but an act done in what is truly the carrying on of a business the amount recovered as appreciation will be assessable.

anchor.surface_text: The question which the High Court had to answer in the present case was a narrow one and the answer to that on the material before the Court was rightly given in the affirmative. But even if the question is taken to be wider in amplitude, on the materials produced and on the facts proved the appellant must be held to have been rightly assessed.
The appeals are therefore dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: if on this material the Tribunal came to the conclusion that there was material to support the finding that the appellant was dealing in shares as a business, it could not be interfered with by the High Court and in our opinion it rightly answered the question against the appellant in the affirmative.
The appeals are therefore dismissed with companyts.

edges.explanation: h4's ruling on no res judicata grounds the propriety of dismissing the S66(1) application despite prior assessment findings
h4 directly addresses whether the Tribunal was barred by prior findings from holding profits as business income, matching i2

anchor.surface_text: The second question is wholly unsubstantial. There is no such thing as res judicata in income-tax matters. The Appellate Tribunal has placed in a tabulated form the activities of the appellant showing the buying and selling and the magnitude of holdings and it cannot be said therefore that it was not open to the Appellate Tribunal to give the finding that it did.
The appeals are therefore dismissed with companyts.
